results.headline: In the Ol’ West, a Very Tough Commute
results.summary_short: Russell Crowe and Christian Bale are the main reasons to see “3:10 to Yuma,” a serviceable addition to the current western revival.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3:10 to Yuma

results.headline: Sexually Inexperienced and Repellently Awkward
results.summary_short: The spirit of Steve Martin’s early hit-or-miss slapstick oddities lives on in the crass goof “The Brothers Solomon.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brothers Solomon

results.headline: Disturbing the Guilty Archives of the Wehrmacht
results.summary_short: “The Unknown Soldier” takes on the idea that ordinary German soldiers were for the most part unaware of and uninvolved in the worst crimes of the Nazi regime.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unknown Soldier

results.headline: Never Mind Those Bullets, a Newborn Needs Rescuing
results.summary_short: “Shoot ’Em Up” is a witless, soulless, heartless movie that mistakes noise for bravura and tastelessness for wit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shoot 'em Up

results.headline: A Mystic’s Early Life
results.summary_short: There are stunning locales but not much subtlety on display in “Milarepa.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Milarepa

results.headline: Three Journalists Find Fear and Loathing on a Serbian War Criminal’s Trail
results.summary_short: “The Hunting Party” is a misfired, misguided would-be satire set in postwar Bosnia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunting Party

results.headline: A Cut Below
results.summary_short: Opening like a Mardi Gras edition of “Girls Gone Wild” and closing with a reverent nod to “Friday the 13th,” “Hatchet” is more concerned with touchstones than with terror.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hatchet

results.headline: The Affairs of a Novelist
results.summary_short: The style of  “The Inner Life of Martin Frost” is aggressively literary, with plummy third-person narration that over-interrogates every development.
results.display_title: The Inner Life of Martin Frost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Inner Life of Martin Frost

results.headline: Surviving in That Rain Forest East of the Delaware River
results.summary_short: When F. Scott Fitzgerald remarked that the rich “are different from you and me,” he might have been thinking of someone like the moody billionaire from “Fierce People.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fierce People

results.headline: Even if You Do Great Art, the Bills Must Still Be Paid
results.summary_short: Daniel Kraus’s “Musician” feels radically fresh: It simply observes its title character in the manner of a 1960s fly-on-the-wall documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Musician

results.headline: Seeking Special Someone but Finding a Giant Pirate
results.summary_short: Imagine Larry David’s HBO’s series, “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” without the bile. That’s the tone of “I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With.”
results.display_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With

results.headline: Clinging to Memories of a Ghost Who Haunts Chile
results.summary_short: One from the heart, “Salvador Allende” is a plaintive look back at the rise and violent fall of the world’s first democratically elected Marxist president.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salvador Allende

results.headline: One Part Evil Killer, One Part Case Study
results.summary_short: Rob  Zombie’s movie, which he wrote and directed, wants us to care about the future serial killer Michael Myers even while it depicts him as a mute, literally faceless grim reaper.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Halloween

results.headline: Gunslingers in Macau: A Far-Eastern Western
results.summary_short: This tale of childhood buddies turned hit men is the kind of film where flames roar, waves crash and dropped bullets thud like bowling balls.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exiled

results.headline: Mysterious Reflections of Hollywood Paranoia
results.summary_short: “The Nines” is a philosophical mind teaser with satirical fangs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nines

results.headline: Spiritual Q & A
results.summary_short: “10 Questions for the Dalai Lama” is a tedious title for an anything-but-tedious film that expertly merges the mystical and the mundane.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Questions for the Dalai Lama

results.headline: A Fairy Tale From India
results.summary_short: “Vanaja” is a coming-of-age tale that is engrossing, if slightly overlong, and absolutely timeless.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanaja

results.headline: Violence in the Name of Justice
results.summary_short: James Wan’s film is a middle-class white man’s payback fantasy, leavened with phony references to class difference.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Sentence

results.headline: A Teenager in Search of a Soul
results.summary_short: Monty Lapica’s film about the self-destructive behavior of a 17-year-old suffers from severe dramatic droop.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Self-Medicated

results.headline: Schemes in Spanish
results.summary_short: This film is like “Ocean’s Eleven” if directed by Robin Hood and financed by Telemundo.
